#Text=Address the Prime Minister
#Text=The prime minister serves as the head of state in a parliamentary government , ranking just below the ruling monarch in terms of executive influence .
#Text=When preparing for a face-to-face meeting with a prime minister , it can be helpful to know the right way to address them .
#Text=Refer to an acting prime minister within their home country as simply , “ Prime Minister , ” followed by their surname if you want to add a touch of formality .
#Text=If you ’re addressing a foreign prime minister , use the honorific , “ Your Excellency ” instead to acknowledge their political stature where they come from .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Speaking to a Prime Minister
#Text=Begin by stating the “ Prime Minister ” title .
#Text=Prefacing your communication with a verbal reference to the official ’s position is a sign of respect .
#Text=From there , you can either proceed with your comment or question or follow up with the person ’s surname for a more formal effect .
#Text=Depending on where you live , it may or may not be acceptable to use the term “ Mr. /Madam/Ms .
#Text=Prime Minister . ”
#Text=This is customary in commonwealth nations , but is generally frowned upon in the U.K. , Canada , Australia , and New Zealand .
#Text=Use , “ Your Excellency ” if the official is outside of their home country .
#Text=This is a traditional form of address meant to indicate good will towards an official who is traveling abroad .
#Text=The reasoning behind the alternative honorific , “ Your Excellency ” is that the person is only the prime minister of the country they serve , whereas internationally they are a revered guest .
#Text=Similarly , you would say , “ His/Her Excellency ” when referring to the prime minister in conversation with another person .
#Text=The phrase , “ Your Excellency ” is also useful for eliminating confusion if the official is visiting another country with its own prime minister .
#Text=Tack on the person ’s surname to follow formal rules of address .
#Text=After stating the initial honorific , attach the official ’s surname .
#Text=If the prime minister ’s name is “ Leslie Goff , ” for example , you would say , “ Prime Minister Goff . ”
#Text=There ’s no need to use their first name .
#Text=Saying , “ Prime Minister Theresa May ” in a personal setting will come off as awkward and unnatural .
#Text=In some cases , it may be alright to switch to a more informal mode of address after your initial show of respect , such as , “ Ms. Spencer . ”
#Text=Avoid using the official ’s first name unless you ’re a close friend .
#Text=The only time it ’s acceptable to call a prime minister by their given name is if you know them very well , and you ’re in a private setting away from other people .
#Text=Otherwise , it ’s best to stick with one of the more respectful honorifics , “ Prime Minister ” or “ Your Excellency . ”
#Text=Be careful not to make the mistake of using the prime minister ’s first name when talking to someone else about them , too .
#Text=Instead of saying , “ Theodore and I were just discussing the issue of misappropriate funds , ” you would want to say , “ Prime Minister Huxley and I … ”
#Text=Writing to a Prime Minister
#Text=Address the envelope to “ The Honourable ( official ’s name ) , M.P. ” The abbreviated form of the title , M.P. , always comes at the end of the first line .
#Text=After naming the official , add a second line spelling out their full title .
#Text=Be sure to specify the name of the country over which they preside , as in , “ Prime Minister of ( name of country ) . ”
#Text=The completed address on the outside of your envelope should look something like this :
#Text=“ The Honourable William Clay , M. P/Prime Minister of Australia . ”
#Text=If the official is distinguished by any other post-nominal identifiers , such as a province key like “ B.C. ” ( “ British Columbia ” ) , be sure to list them right after “ M.P.”{{greenbox :
#Text=Tip : Use the more traditional phrase , “ The Right Honourable ” when referring to the prime minister of the U.K. or Canada in particular . } }
#Text=Open your letter with the salutation , “ Dear Prime Minister . ”
#Text=If you like , you can go on to add the official ’s surname , though this is n’t a necessity .
#Text=Your salutation should either read , “ Dear Prime Minister , ” or , “ Dear Prime Minister Bentley ” .
#Text=Do n’t try to get fancy with the salutation .
#Text=Start with the same one you would use for any other formal letter , “ Dear . ”
#Text=You also have the option of foregoing a salutation altogether by simply saying , “ Prime Minister ” or , “ Prime Minister Bentley . ”
#Text=Use , “ His/Her Excellency ” when writing to a foreign prime minister .
#Text=Do n’t forget to include a second line naming the official ’s full title and home country , just as you would for an ordinary address .
#Text=Your completed address will say something like , “ Her Excellency Indira Gandhi/Prime Minister of India . ”
#Text=“ His/Her Excellency ” is the correct grammatical format for the outside of an envelope , not , “ Your Excellency , ” which should only be used when addressing the official directly .
#Text=Sign off with the closing , “ Yours faithfully , ” or something similar .
#Text=You could also say , “ Yours sincerely ” or , “ Yours respectfully . ”
#Text=The important thing is to extend one final gesture of admiration before ending your letter .
#Text=Sign your letter with your full name , along with any titles you may have that are relevant to your reason for writing .
#Text=As with your salutation , resist the urge to try to dress up your closing too much .
#Text=A simple and respectful tone tends to work best .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Follow the same guidelines you would use to compose a formal letter when typing up an email .

#Text=Anytime you ’re writing to someone of high office , take some time to ensure that your handwriting is clearly legible , and that the language you use is appropriate for the nature of your correspondence .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Using an incorrect mode of address , while not a punishable offense , may be considered a faux pas , and definitely is n’t the best way to make a good first impression .
